content: I just made some minor edits to a few test cases where you had a trailing newline on the input. This is just to keep them consistent and because those trailing newlines can complicate things in shortest mode where some languages will need to use extra characters removing the last newline to solve it. Nice clash. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Shortest (<70 chars) + Fastest OK

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice challenge - a very good ratio between input (1 line) and required steps to solve it (>1).

Since reverse is enabled I was studying the cases without the statement first - and had no clue at all. I think it is especially challenging to establish the pattern because test 2 does not really give a clue, test 3 and test 4 are impossible to use as a reverse player, so it's really up to only test 1 and 5 to establish the pattern. It might be doable, but it would not hurt if you include a couple more with <10 values for reverse players.

NB once I read the statement and understood what needed to be done, I looked forward to coding up the solution - it is a nice challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Clash. Issues raised by others seem to have been addressed and fixed. Good for Fastest and Shortest modes, not so sure about Reverse... but Nice clash none the less.

Happy Coding!

Hi there @The Goat 2000, I saw your title for this clash... and I was wondering about it. Is it in any way related the the Pink Floyd song of the same name?

(Pink Floyd -- Another Brick in the Wall)

Just asking partly out of curiosity and partly because another codingamer couldn't see how the title related to the clash itself. You do NOT NEED to change the title, just wondering.

Nice Contribution though. I believe that all the issues raised by @5DN1L and the others have been fixed by you, as in the comments below. Everything is formatted quite nicely, so I will approve.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Issues have not been fixed

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: As @WhoTho states, Test 3 violates the third constraint. There is no mention of how to resolve the case where there are equal elements.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Testcase 3 includes a duplicate number, which breaks some solutions that should work. Fix it and it'll be good.

I'm just refusing for now so hopefully people will check why and not accept the clash without thinking.
I'm still looking for the relationship between the Title and your goal ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: its short

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: il faut un peu plus que 5 minutes pour le résoudre

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: the statement is incorrect
This is gold

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: please read this comment before approve it (and please help to find out what's wrong)

tl;dr:  test cases and solution code is wrong

and except these in below as nireda said 5 days ago your test cases are very few and very common and you didn't fix that
we have two possibility:
1. the statement is incorrect 
2. the solution code and test cases are absolutely wrong
in both cases it's a valid reason to reject
I hope I'm wrong because it means people who approve it never check the answers

let's jump to problem, you said "The teacher will assign the student with the most depression value 1 homework, and the student with the least depression value N homework(s)" and in output you said "N space-separated integers denoting the amounts of homework (from 1 to N) to assign to the students, in the *same order as input*"
it means we have two number per student depression and index of input, and to find number of homework we have to reverse sort them by their depression the index of sorted list + 1 is the amount of homework because the highest depression person have the 0+1 homework and the least one have N-1 + 1 homework

(sorry for my tone in below I couldn't keep myself anymore)
but your code just sort them and then print N -  index what the ..?
what is in your mind? you give 100 random number that no one can understand it but I read them one by one and checked every number and all of them incorrect let me give one case that your code fail and everyone can understand
case 1: 
8
23 83 56 24 15 46 92 13
the answer (by myself): 6 2 3 5 7 4 1 8
my code answer: 6 2 3 5 7 4 1 8
your solution answer:  1 4 8 5 3 6 7 2
ahhhh... too much time debugging to understand what happend
here is my code:
```py
n = int(input())
depression_values = [0]*n
assignments = [0]*n

for student_index, depression in enumerate(input().split()):
    depression_values[student_index] = int(depression) 

for assignments_count, student_index in enumerate(sorted(range(n), key=lambda student_index: depression_values[student_index], reverse=True)):
    assignments[student_index] = assignments_count+1

print(*assignments)
```
As a psychologist, I think it's best to assign the student with the most depression 0 homework (also it makes solving  the puzzle a little bit slower);nice puzzle!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash and small solution, good job ;). The test cases look good to me, well done.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The "validators" tests are not usable by users for debugging. One more test case should be added (see my comment below) until I can validate submit. 

Suggestion :
Also why do you call your variable s_i on entry line 2 ? Seems confusig to me, you could just call it "s" as you precise after "for i from 1 to N".

Good but I would add one more test case similar to the test 1 

You could make a entry :
4
2 3 42 1

This in order to make debug easier for players when you're in the clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is very good and perfect.
Continue like that !

Input
* Please format the line numbers in <<bold>>.

* Please add "for the number of students" to LIne 1.

* Please add "for the depression values of the students" to Line 2.

Output
* Suggest to change to:
<<Line 1>>: [[N]] space-separated integers denoting the amounts of homework (from 1 to [[N]]) to assign to the students, in the same order as input

Thanks.
Fixed :)
s is an ordered set of numbers
One of my friends at England is planning to become a physhologyst when he go to uni
Ok thank you
K I fixed
Removed reverse
it's easy actually at first my code did that so I have to add one to the answers
Thank you. Hope you aren't one of those students with high depression values!
